comment_text.mn57:1.2: The Koliyans were south-eastern neighbors of the Sakyans, with whom they had close ties in marriage and customs. | Haliddavasana (“yellow-clothes”) is also the scene of SN 46.54, which discusses similarities and differences between Buddhism and wanderers when it comes to meditation.
comment_text.mn57:2.1: The cow votary (govatika) is attested in Sanskrit (eg. Mahābhārata 5.97.13). Elsewhere, non-Buddhist texts mention cat votaries (Manu 4.30), snake votaries, fish votaries, those who live like beasts (mṛgacaryā), and others, but not, so far as I am aware, dog votaries. The cow and dog observances are found in later Buddhist texts (Yogacārabhūmi 157.10, Mahākarmavibhaṅga 44.19, Śikṣāsamuccaya 332.3, etc.) evidently drawing from this sutta. Thus, while no parallel of this sutta has survived, it was known in northern Buddhist traditions and must have been lost due to a failure of transmission.
comment_text.mn57:4.8: From a text of a later date, the cow observance is described thus: “One should bathe in the urine of a cow, maintain himself with milk, and move with the cows, eating after they had eaten. It is known as govrata. One would become free from the sins in a month. He would attain the world of cows and reach heaven” (Agni Purāna 292:12–13a, Gangadharan’s translation). This is not a penance for burning off sin, but rather a way of elevating oneself through the sacred nature of the cow. It is not clear, however, if this is the same as the observance in the Buddha’s day.
comment_text.mn57:5.2: This means to be reborn as a cow, rather than in the goloka, which in Hinduism is a heaven for cows.
comment_text.mn57:7.5: By treating ethical decisions via a tetralemma, the Buddha rejects the “law of the excluded middle” and the consequent belief that acts must be either right or wrong.
comment_text.mn57:7.6: These are the intentions associated with the noble eightfold path.
comment_text.mn57:12.4: Puṇṇa the layman goes for refuge, while Seniya the ascetic goes forth.
comment_text.mn57:13.5: In the early period, there was no distinction between “going forth” (pabbajjā) and “ordination” (upasampadā). They refer to two sides of the same coin: leaving the home life and entering the ascetic life. Ordination was originally granted by the Buddha with the simple call, “Come mendicant!” (Kd 1:6.32.1). As the community grew, the Buddha authorized the Saṅgha to perform the “going forth and ordination” (Kd 1:12.1.1). Later still, the novice (sāmaṇera) platform was introduced for teenagers and became known as “going forth” (Kd 1:54.3.2). Finally, the novice ordination was standardized for all ordinands, even if it was a mere preliminary for the “full ordination”.
comment_text.mn57:14.1: This probation is laid down in the Vinaya at Kd 1:38.1.5. The candidate shaves, dons the robes, takes refuge, and asks for probation. They must show good conduct and restraint, diligence in duties, and enthusiasm for the Buddha’s teachings and practice.
comment_text.mn57:14.2: In addition to individual exceptions, there are general exceptions for dreadlocked fire-worshipping ascetics, since they believe in kamma, and for the Buddha’s relatives (Kd 1:38.11.3).

translation_text.mn57:0.2: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog
translation_text.mn57:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Koliyans, where they have a town named Haliddavasana.
translation_text.mn57:2.1: Then Puṇṇa the Koliyan, a cow votary, and the naked ascetic Seniya, a dog votary, went to see the Buddha. Puṇṇa bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side, while Seniya exchanged greetings and polite conversation with him before sitting down to one side curled up like a dog.
translation_text.mn57:2.3: “Sir, this naked ascetic Seniya the dog votary does a hard thing: he eats food placed on the ground.
translation_text.mn57:2.4: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a dog.
translation_text.mn57:2.5: Where will he be reborn in his next life?”
translation_text.mn57:2.6: “Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.”
translation_text.mn57:2.8: and a third time, Puṇṇa said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn57:2.9: “Sir, this naked ascetic Seniya does a hard thing: he eats food placed on the ground.
translation_text.mn57:2.10: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a dog.
translation_text.mn57:2.11: Where will he be reborn in his next life?”
translation_text.mn57:2.12: “Clearly, Puṇṇa, I’m not getting through to you when I say:
translation_text.mn57:2.13: ‘Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’
translation_text.mn57:3.1: Take someone who develops the dog observance fully and uninterruptedly. They develop a dog’s ethics, a dog’s mentality, and a dog’s behavior fully and uninterruptedly.
translation_text.mn57:3.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of dogs.
translation_text.mn57:3.3: But if they have such a view: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’ This is their wrong view.
translation_text.mn57:3.4: An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say: hell or the animal realm.
translation_text.mn57:3.5: So if the dog observance succeeds it leads to rebirth in the company of dogs, but if it fails it leads to hell.”
translation_text.mn57:4.1: When he said this, Seniya cried and burst out in tears.
translation_text.mn57:4.3: “This is what I didn’t get through to you when I said:
translation_text.mn57:4.4: ‘Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’”
translation_text.mn57:4.5: Seniya said, “Sir, I’m not crying because of what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn57:4.6: But, sir, for a long time I have undertaken this observance to behave like a dog.
translation_text.mn57:4.7: Sir, this Puṇṇa is a cow votary.
translation_text.mn57:4.8: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a cow.
translation_text.mn57:4.9: Where will he be reborn in his next life?”
translation_text.mn57:4.10: “Enough, Seniya, let it be. Don’t ask me that.”
translation_text.mn57:4.12: and a third time Seniya said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn57:4.13: “Sir, this Puṇṇa is a cow votary.
translation_text.mn57:4.14: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a cow.
translation_text.mn57:4.15: Where will he be reborn in his next life?”
translation_text.mn57:4.16: “Clearly, Seniya, I’m not getting through to you when I say:
translation_text.mn57:4.17: ‘Enough, Seniya, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’
translation_text.mn57:5.1: Take someone who develops the cow observance fully and uninterruptedly. They develop a cow’s ethics, a cow’s mentality, and a cow’s behavior fully and uninterruptedly.
translation_text.mn57:5.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of cows.
translation_text.mn57:5.3: But if they have such a view: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’ This is their wrong view.
translation_text.mn57:5.4: An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say: hell or the animal realm.
translation_text.mn57:5.5: So if the cow observance succeeds it leads to rebirth in the company of cows, but if it fails it leads to hell.”
translation_text.mn57:6.1: When he said this, Puṇṇa cried and burst out in tears.
translation_text.mn57:6.3: “This is what I didn’t get through to you when I said:
translation_text.mn57:6.4: ‘Enough, Seniya, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’”
translation_text.mn57:6.5: Puṇṇa said, “Sir, I’m not crying because of what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn57:6.6: But, sir, for a long time I have undertaken this observance to behave like a cow.
translation_text.mn57:6.7: I am quite confident that the Buddha
translation_text.mn57:6.8: is capable of teaching me so that I can give up this cow observance, and the naked ascetic Seniya can give up that dog observance.”
translation_text.mn57:6.9: “Well then, Puṇṇa, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn57:7.1: “Puṇṇa, I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight.
translation_text.mn57:7.3: There are dark deeds with dark results;
translation_text.mn57:7.5: dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results; and
translation_text.mn57:7.6: neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.
translation_text.mn57:8.1: And what are dark deeds with dark results?
translation_text.mn57:8.2: It’s when someone makes hurtful choices by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn57:8.3: Having made these choices, they’re reborn in a hurtful world,
translation_text.mn57:8.5: Touched by hurtful contacts, they experience hurtful feelings that are exclusively painful—like the beings in hell.
translation_text.mn57:8.6: This is how a being is born from a being.
translation_text.mn57:8.7: For your deeds determine your rebirth,
translation_text.mn57:8.8: and when you’re reborn contacts strike you.
translation_text.mn57:8.9: This is why I say that sentient beings are heirs to their deeds.
translation_text.mn57:8.10: These are called dark deeds with dark results.
translation_text.mn57:9.1: And what are bright deeds with bright results?
translation_text.mn57:9.2: It’s when someone makes pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn57:9.3: Having made these choices, they are reborn in a pleasing world,
translation_text.mn57:9.5: Touched by pleasing contacts, they experience pleasing feelings of perfect happiness—like the gods of universal beauty.
translation_text.mn57:9.6: This is how a being is born from a being.
translation_text.mn57:9.7: For your deeds determine your rebirth,
translation_text.mn57:9.8: and when you’re reborn contacts strike you.
translation_text.mn57:9.9: This is why I say that sentient beings are heirs to their deeds.
translation_text.mn57:9.10: These are called bright deeds with bright results.
translation_text.mn57:10.1: And what are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results?
translation_text.mn57:10.2: It’s when someone makes both hurtful and pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn57:10.3: Having made these choices, they are reborn in a world that is both hurtful and pleasing,
translation_text.mn57:10.4: where hurtful and pleasing contacts strike them.
translation_text.mn57:10.5: Touched by both hurtful and pleasing contacts, they experience both hurtful and pleasing feelings that are a mixture of pleasure and pain—like humans, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.
translation_text.mn57:10.6: This is how a being is born from a being.
translation_text.mn57:10.7: For what you do brings about your rebirth,
translation_text.mn57:10.8: and when you’re reborn contacts strike you.
translation_text.mn57:10.9: This is why I say that sentient beings are heirs to their deeds.
translation_text.mn57:10.10: These are called dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results.
translation_text.mn57:11.1: And what are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds?
translation_text.mn57:11.2: It’s the intention to give up dark deeds with dark results, bright deeds with bright results, and both dark and bright deeds with both dark and bright results.
translation_text.mn57:11.3: These are called neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.
translation_text.mn57:11.4: These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”
translation_text.mn57:12.1: When he had spoken, Puṇṇa the Koliyan said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn57:12.4: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
translation_text.mn57:13.1: And Seniya the naked ascetic said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn57:13.4: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn57:13.5: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
translation_text.mn57:14.1: “Seniya, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.
translation_text.mn57:14.2: However, I recognize individual differences in this matter.”
translation_text.mn57:14.3: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”
translation_text.mn57:15.1: And the naked ascetic Seniya received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
translation_text.mn57:15.2: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Seniya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn57:15.3: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
translation_text.mn57:15.4: And Venerable Seniya became one of the perfected.
